newsitem.title: TURKEY: U.S-Turkish ties face new strain.
newsitem.headline: U.S-Turkish ties face new strain.

text.p: The United States did not consult Turkey's Islamist premier before firing dozens of cruise missiles at Iraq, diplomats and officials said on Wednesday.
The U.S. attitude underlined its mistrust of Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan's leadership and could put at risk Western enforcement of the no-fly zone over Iraq's rebel north, they said.
Senior officials and diplomats said the United States had not consulted Erbakan before firing dozens of cruise missiles at his big southern neighbour on Tuesday and Wednesday.

Nor, they said, did Washington ask NATO-member Turkey for permission to use its Incirlik airbase to stage the attacks, fearing a rebuff. The base is already home to U.S., British and French jets patrolling the skies over northern Iraq.
"Turkey was informed but not necessarily consulted," a western diplomat told Reuters.

That posture, say analysts, could undercut the West's policy of containment against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein -- based on the twin pillars of military exclusion zones to protect restive Iraqi minorities and crippling economic sanctions.
"They certainly seemed to have by-passed Erbakan," the diplomat said.
Instead, the U.S. embassy in Ankara handed a brief message from President Bill Clinton to Foreign Minister Tansu Ciller, the pro-Western junior coalition partner.
Turkish and U.S. sources confirmed this account, highlighting a groundswell of uneasiness between the two countries since Erbakan, secular Turkey's first Islamist leader, took power in June.
Erbakan has not commented on the U.S. missile attacks, brushing aside reporters' questions about the subject.

"Relations are formed between equals, this is a rule of protocol," said one senior Turkish official. "But the United States, seeing itself as a superpower, has often ignored international rules of protocol."

The prime minister, whose Islam-based Welfare Party campaigned on an end to Turkey's NATO role amid a general turn to the East, makes Washington uncomfortable, he said. "The Americans do not find Erbakan's attitude one of respect."

The result is a policy of neglect that threatens Turkey's continued support for the U.S.-led air patrols over northern Iraq -- known as Operation Provide Comfort by the allies and as Poised Hammer by the Turks.

Already, Erbakan has bowed to pressure from Washington and its friends in the Turkish military, reversing his long-standing opposition to Provide Comfort and forcing renewal of the mission through a sceptical parliament in July.
Fresh approval is required in late December and passage is far from assured.
"I think the Turkish angle has been neglected," acknowledged one NATO diplomat. "It will make it that much harder to win approval for Provide Comfort next time."
There is more of "a comfort zone" with Ciller, Erbakan's U.S.-educated predecessor and now foreign minister, he said.
Erbakan has long touted a realignment of Turkish foreign policy, warming toward neighbours Iraq, Iran and Syria at the expense of the West, Washington in particular.
Turkey is also itching to restore trade ties with Iraq, its third biggest partner before U.N. sanctions were slapped on Baghdad for its 1990 invasion of Kuwait.
